It is profusely decorated, and the value of its contents must add up to millions of dollars. Lots of bad things could be said about Bordurian generals, but one can't deny they have good taste. A window looks into the garden.

It's a score of the Piano Concerto no. 3 by Béla Bartók. He wrote it when he was suffering from terminal leukemia, and he dedicated it to his wife, they say. Tragic.

DescriptionList.Description: A tiny golden button, subtly camouflaged in the Lanfranco's frame. Not a bad trick, most people wouldn't bother to look closely at that painting.

Standard red blankets, nothing interesting.

DescriptionList.Description: A sumptuous Persian carpet, decorated with intrincate geometric patterns.

Item.name: Caja fuerte

DescriptionList.Description: The safe is a Wuttengeiser model XL-44 "Rottweiler". A very good, burglar-proof strongbox. You calculate that it could take you about three minutes to force it.

Item.name: Cuadro

DescriptionList.Description: A large painting with a golden frame, perhaps one meter wide per two meters tall. If your memory doesn't fail you, it is Giovanni Lanfranco's "Resurrection". But the flag in the original painting has been replaced by a Bordurian flag. OK, maybe Bordurian generals don't have such a good taste after all.
The original flag in Lanfranco's painting has been replaced by a Bordurian flag in this reproduction.

DescriptionList.Description: A rather tacky golden frame, decorated with geometric patterns.
Geometric patterns.
Your are as calculatingly beautiful as always. Blonde, with a suggestive cleavage and dressed up to perfection. Otherwise, Kovacic wouldn't have hired you.
